author: dcspark
title: AI Stablecoin & Oracle Hackathon
description: Muchos desarrolladores de Ethereum no saben que pueden desplegar su contrato en Cardano a través de Milkomeda

f6_assessments.q0: Great idea by a team which has the ability to deliver. The proposal could however have a little more in the way of details (how many people, format of the hackathon etc).
f6_assessments.q1: The team should be well equipped to deliver this idea. Unfortunately, as with a number of other proposals by the dcSpark team, reviewers and voters are left to trust the prospers to deliver on the idea without the proposers providing a clear roadmap. Thus without a clear plan having been presented I cannot give this a high probability of success, even though I believe the proposers have the ability. Please provide us with a more detailed outline on what will be done, when.
f6_assessments.q2: There is not enough detail to audit this proposal. Other than there will be a hackathon in H1 2022, we don't have anything in the way of details of what will be delivered. How many people will enter/participate in the hackathon. What is the format, how will it be marketed. What would you consider success? Number of participants, media exposure, entries that go on to be projects self funded of receiving funding elsewhere?

f6_assessments.q0: The essence of this proposal is marketing-based, through means of a hackathon to create an AI-stablecoin. The k-framework enables any code to run on the LLVM through means of the IELE-protocol. wADA would effectively create a bridge between multiple blockchains and thus create more usecases in the long run. Using the M1-sidechain to realise this, buffers anything going through, so ensuring all chains' involved robustness. All ecosystems benefit.
f6_assessments.q1: This project has an extremely experienced team who possess, without any doubt, the needed competencies. However, the requested funds is 15% of the challenge budget and voters might not be willing to reserve such an amount for an existing project's hackathon while there are also brand new projects in the same challenge that are requesting funds.
f6_assessments.q2: Project roadmap is available on the website, along with detailed team identification. The information on the plan is quite vague as to what extent AI is applicable. This is important as the proposal is filed under an AI-centric challenge. So to improve this proposal, additional information on how the AI comes into play is advised.

f6_assessments.q0: There is a need to attract programmers to this exciting new field of Blockchain-powered AI. THerefore conducting such Hackaton by established entities like dcSpark will go a long way in bringing programming talents to the echo system.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers are ex IOHK and other Cardano base companies, with a very high stake in the success of Cardano. Moreover, the plan presented is doable and is practical. THerefore there is a very high chance that the proposal will be implemented.
f6_assessments.q2: The expenditure is proposed for the prizes to be given in the Hackaton with the proposing company dcSparks will do the other administrative support. The prize money will be in the open, and the output will likely add value to the ecosystem. Therefore the proposal is auditable.

f6_assessments.q0: Interesting idea to spark awareness about AI and Cardano. By organizing a Hackathon this project basically provides a platform where the best idea can come forth. This fits well within the challenge settings because both platform benefit from this.
f6_assessments.q1: Regarding the team behind the proposal, I have no doubt they possess the right qualifications to bring this project to success. We get all the information needed on the team from the website. The roadmap is also provided on the website and is well defined. By organizing a Hackathon with a prize pool of 75K will certainly attract valuable players.
f6_assessments.q2: As we have already seen on the above rationale the roadmap is provided on the website. What I would've like to see is what success looks like in the eyes of the proposers.

f6_assessments.q0: Hackathons are one of the potential directions stated in the challenge, and the proposed hackathon is linked to AI. However, there is no particular connection to SingularityNet, and no detail on what the hackathon would be about (and for a budget of $75K it seems fair to require more detail about the content of the hackathon). Therefore, I neither agree nor disagree that the proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
This team includes several experienced developers with excellent Cardano experience and track record. They certainly should know how to organize a hackathon.

However, the team seems to have fairly limited expertise in AI, apparently primarily the work by Sebastien Guillemot at Microsoft Bing in 2017-2018. 

Therefore, I agree but do not strongly agree that the plan presented is highly likely to be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: While the project is straightforward, there are no KPIs provided. And as noted above there is very little information on the content of the hackathon. For these reasons, I disagree that there is sufficient information to audit the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is about hosting a virtual hackathon for individuals & companies in domains that overlap w/ AI and sharing knowledge about Cardano & Ethereum. This is a great idea. The problem is clear, suitable to the given challenge, however, the proposed solution remains very abstract [without a roadmap, budget breakdown, and KPIs,...].
Therefore, based on the given information, I disagree with this proposal's impact, I can rate it with a score of 2
f6_assessments.q1: Team profile is provided and described enough for understanding, with suitable skill, and experiences for implementation, with reference/proof (https://dcspark.gitbook.io/milkomeda/details/team) for verifying. So, the team profile convinces me of feasibility. However, the plan did not. The budget breakdown with only the total budget, There is not any roadmap/milestones. Besides, the risk is not defined. Therefore, based on the given information, I am neutral with this proposal's feasibility, I can rate it with a score of 3
f6_assessments.q2:
Team profile is provided and described enough for understanding with reference/proof (documents/links,...) for verifying. My advice is: for better understanding about the plan, the proposer should consider adding the missing information: (1) Budget distribution (with explanation for each item); (2) Roadmap (with KPIs/ Metrics); (3) Risk/challenge analysis
Based on the given information, I disagree with this proposal's auditability, I can rate it with a score of 2

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal implements the organization of a virtual hackathon for individuals and companies in the fields of AI. The proponent submitted more than 20 proposals at fund 7 and 5 of them are hackathons, I think the team has experience in organizing, but in the proposal I have not seen the organizational plan. Will the hackathon be online/offline or another way, has the covid difficulty been taken into account?
f6_assessments.q1: The proposed team consists of many members with experience working in the blockchain environment, but it is difficult to find any member's social media pages. What is the topic you will organize the hackathon, how the organization will be done, rules, communication ... a lot of information needs to be added. The budget suggested total and 5000 for the organization work, I understand the remaining amount is for prizes so the team has also calculated the prizes.
f6_assessments.q2: How the challenges and risks will affect the organization of the hackathon. There is a lot of missing information, a timeline for the organization. After holding the hackathon, do you have any next plan? What are the desired KPIs after this competition? How many participants, how many prizes?, how many products? ...

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal to host an AI Stablecoin and Oracle hackathon effectively addresses the fund7 AI challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: The dcSpark core dev team is made up of ex-Emurgo and ex-IOHK developers responsible for building wallet infrastructure and building crucial sidechain tech for Jormungandr. The team has deployed Milkomeda to testnet and is now looking to begin hosting hackathons for dev teams deploying in it.
f6_assessments.q2: The info presented in the detailed plan section of the proposal along with the high level timeline given is sufficient to audit the proposal.

solution: Organizaremos un hackathon virtual para individuos y empresas en dominios que se solapan con la IA y compartiremos nuestros conocimientos sobre Cardano y Ethereum
experience: Nuestro equipo está compuesto por conocidos ex empleados de Emurgo y ex empleados de IOHK que han estado construyendo el ecosistema de Cardano durante los últimos años
